string-array.name: wiki_basics_sub_origin_points
string-array.item: Earthquakes start along plate boundaries or local faults where stress builds until rocks suddenly slip.
The hypocenter is the underground start of the rupture; the epicenter is the point directly above it on the surface.
Foreshocks and aftershocks are smaller events related to the same fault adjustment.

string-array.name: wiki_basics_sub_scale_points
string-array.item: Magnitude measures the total energy released by the earthquake.
Intensity varies by distance, ground type, and building design in each location.
Large quakes can produce very different intensities across nearby neighborhoods—expect uneven damage.

string-array.name: wiki_basics_sub_signals_points
string-array.item: Some regions have early warning apps that send alerts seconds before strong shaking arrives.
Set your phone to receive government emergency alerts and local civil-defense messages.
Trust official notifications over rumors—false alarms waste precious seconds.

string-array.name: wiki_before_sub_home_points
string-array.item: Bolt tall furniture, heaters, and water tanks to wall studs.
Install latches on cabinets and secure heavy décor away from beds or seating areas.
Know how to shut off gas, electricity, and water if authorities advise.
Identify sturdy shelter spots under tables or against interior walls.

string-array.name: wiki_before_sub_plan_points
string-array.item: Choose an out-of-area contact everyone can message if local networks are busy.
Agree on two meeting spots: one near home and another outside the neighborhood.
Teach children how and when to dial emergency services.

string-array.name: wiki_before_sub_drills_points
string-array.item: Run Drop-Cover-Hold drills at least twice a year in every room you use.
Update alert apps and check batteries in radios or flashlights every season.
Take community response training to learn basic rescue and fire suppression.

string-array.name: wiki_during_sub_indoor_points
string-array.item: Drop to your hands and knees so you are not knocked over.
Cover your head and neck under a sturdy table or desk.
Hold on to your shelter until the shaking stops.
Stay indoors—doorways are not stronger than other parts of the room.

string-array.name: wiki_during_sub_outdoor_points
string-array.item: Move away from buildings, trees, power lines, and bridges.
If driving, pull over safely, set the parking brake, and stay inside the vehicle.
Avoid stopping under overpasses, signs, or on steep slopes.

string-array.name: wiki_during_sub_special_points
string-array.item: If you use a wheelchair, lock the wheels and protect your head with your arms or a cushion.
If you are in bed, stay where you are, cover your head, and wait for the shaking to end.
In crowded places, stay put, shield your head, and move cautiously once it is safe.

string-array.name: wiki_after_sub_check_points
string-array.item: Expect aftershocks—leave damaged structures calmly and move to open space if needed.
Check for fire, gas smells, or sparking wires before flipping switches.
If you suspect a gas leak, open windows, leave the building, and report it.

string-array.name: wiki_after_sub_help_points
string-array.item: Provide first aid with the supplies in your kit until professional help arrives.
Reassure children with simple language and keep families together.
Keep pets on leashes or in carriers; debris and noise can disorient them.

string-array.name: wiki_after_sub_stayinformed_points
string-array.item: Use a battery radio or phone alerts for evacuation orders and updates.
Send text messages instead of making voice calls to ease network congestion.
Follow official guidance before entering damaged buildings.

string-array.name: wiki_kit_sub_basic_points
string-array.item: One gallon (3.8 L) of water per person per day for at least three days.
Non-perishable food and a manual can opener.
Flashlight, spare batteries, headlamp, and whistle.
Basic first-aid supplies, medications, and personal hygiene items.

string-array.name: wiki_kit_sub_docs_points
string-array.item: Copies of IDs, insurance policies, and prescriptions sealed in waterproof bags.
Multi-tool, gloves, sturdy shoes, and duct tape.
Small bills, an emergency contact list, and local maps.

string-array.name: wiki_kit_sub_maintenance_points
string-array.item: Review and rotate food, water, and medications every six months.
Adjust supplies for infants, seniors, and pets as needs change.
Store kits in easy-to-grab spots at home, work, and in your vehicle.
